text: Herschel–Bulkley formulation for non-Newtonian flows Features: • Yield stress 𝜏𝑦 • Power law dependance on the strain rate – Shear thinning for 𝑛 < 1. – Shear thickening for 𝑛 > 1. • Bingham model for 𝑛 = 1. • Newtonian fluid for 𝑛 = 1 and 𝜏𝑦 = 0. 𝜀-formulation 𝜏 = 𝜏𝑦 ℐ + 𝐾 (2𝒟)𝑛 = 2[ 𝜏𝑦 2‖𝒟‖ + 𝜀 ℐ + 𝐾 (2‖𝒟‖ + 𝜖)𝑛−1]𝒟. Normalizing stresses with 𝛾/𝑅0, length with 𝑅0, and velocity with √𝛾/𝜌𝑙𝑅0… ̃𝜏 = 2[ 𝒥 2‖ ̃𝒟‖ + 𝜀 ℐ + 𝑂ℎ𝐾 (2‖ ̃𝒟‖ + 𝜖)𝑛−1] ̃𝒟. Here, the effective Ohnesorge is 𝑂ℎ𝐾 = 𝐾 √𝜌𝑛 𝑙 𝛾2−𝑛𝑅3𝑛−2 0 The plasto-capillary number 𝒥 is 𝒥 = 𝜏𝑦𝑅0 𝛾 One can easily see that putting 𝑛 = 1 recovers the Bingham model with 𝑂ℎ = 𝜂𝑙/√𝜌𝑙𝛾𝑅0. Additionally, with 𝑛 = 1 & 𝒥 = 0, the model will give a Newtonian response. Calculate the equivalent viscosity Factorizing with 2𝒟𝑖𝑗 to obtain an equivalent viscosity 𝜂eff = 𝒥 2‖ ̃𝒟‖ + 𝜀 ℐ + 𝑂ℎ𝐾 (2‖ ̃𝒟‖ + 𝜖)𝑛−1 In this formulation, 𝜀 is a small number to ensure numerical stability. The term 𝜏𝑦 𝜀 + ... is equivalent to the 𝜇𝑚𝑎𝑥 of the previous (v1.0, see: GitHub) formulation [2]. Note: The fluid flows always, it is not a solid, but a very viscous fluid. Reproduced from: P.-Y. Lagrée’s Sandbox. Here, we use a face implementation of the regularisation method, described here.
